brat_format_output.text: Crystallization kinetics , spherulitic growth and morphology development in non ‑ polar polymer blend with strong dynamic asymmetry
Nithin Chandran 1,2 · C. Sarathchandran3 · Anjaly Sivadas1 · Robert A. Shanks4
Received : 27 December 2024 / Revised : 14 February 2025 / Accepted : 9 March 2025 © The Author ( s ) , under exclusive licence to Springer - Verlag GmbH Germany , part of Springer Nature 2025
Abstract

The crystallization kinetics , spherulitic growth rate and morphology development of a non-polar blend mixture [ isotactic polypropylene ( iPP ) and natural rubber ( NR ) ] with strong dynamic asymmetry are investigated comprehensively . Melt mixed samples of iPP and natural NR with different NR loading were subjected to ther - mal analysis using differential scanning calorimetry ( DSC ) and thermogravimetric ( TGA ) followed by crystal growth using optical microscopy ( OM ) . Prior to melt mixing , the NR samples were masticated for 30 min so as to reduce the molecular weight . Detailed evaluation of the kinetics of crystallization , growth rate of crystals , and morphology development in a dynamically asymmetric system is challenging especially when the second component is a semi-crystalline polymer and studies on such systems have not received significant attention .
Introduction

Mixing two or more polymers is a well - established approach for designing materials with specific end use [ 1 ] . Changes in inherent characteristics and processing conditions of the component polymers are the main factors that influence the ultimate properties of polymer blends . Morphology and thermal properties of individual polymers play a major role in the precise manipulation of the properties ( mechanical , optical , electrical , etc. ) , thereby leading to the successful development of polymer blends with a unique set of properties . The situation is far more challenging when one of the blend compo - nents is a semi-crystalline polymer due to several competing reactions , including phase separation , nucleation and crystal growth , ripening of crystal structure , etc. . However , semi-crystalline polymers and their blends are quite extensively used in the automo - bile industry . Thereby , it is of industrial / academic interest to study the crystallization behavior of immiscible blend systems especially with dynamic asymmetry . This can be achieved by the addition of a high molecular weight additive to the semi-crystalline polymer matrix [ 2 – 4 ] . The influence of introducing low molecular weight additives [ 5 – 7 ] and fillers [ 8 – 10 ] have been extensively investigated . Even then , the effect of add - ing high molecular weight additives such as elastomers , block copolymers [ 11 , 12 ] etc. , to a semi-crystalline polymer matrix has not received significant attention .

The ease of processability , coupled with desirable characteristics / properties , makes polypropylene ( iPP ) an appealing thermoplastic for broad applications rang - ing from the automotive industry to biomedical industry [ 13 ] making it the best candidate for the present study . Even though the crystallization kinetics and mor - phology of iPP - based blends [ 14 – 19 ] and the influence of additives ( especially those of low molecular weight ) on the crystallization and morphology of semi-crystalline polymers have already been investigated [ 20 , 21 ] . The influence of adding a high molecular weight polymer on segmental dynamics , crystallization kinetics and ther - mal stability remains unexplored and requires special attention . Rheological , mor - phological and mechanical properties of high molecular weight NR blended with PP have been extensively studied [ 22 – 24 ] . But an in - depth analysis of the thermal prop - erties of iPP - NR blends is not available especially , while using NR as a toughening agent . The very large difference in molecular weight between iPP and NR makes them a dynamically asymmetric system . Since the role of NR as a toughening agent for iPP was the main aim of present work , fillers were not used as this would inhibit the contribution of NR to morphology development and , in turn , mechanical proper - ties . The current manuscript ushers to provide fundamental insights into the crystal - lization kinetics , morphology development and thermal stability of a dynamic asym - metric blend with a semi-crystalline component .

The current research deals with subjecting the blends to different thermal his - tories to determine the glass transition temperature ( Tg ) , melting temperature ( Tm ) , and melting enthalpy ( ΔHm ) using DSC . Apart from these , isothermal crystalliza - tion experiments were carried out to determine the half - time of crystallization ( t 0.5 ) and the kinetic parameters , which include the Avrami exponent ( n ) and the overall rate of crystallization ( K1 / n ) . Besides , the spherulitic growth of the blend has been followed using polarizing optical microscopy ( POM ) .
Experimental
Materials

iPP ( Repol - H350 FG ) was supplied by Reliance Industries Limited with melt flow index , ( 230 °C / 2.16 kg ) of 38 g / min and heat deflection temperature ( 455 kPa ) of 104 °C . Natural rubber ( ISNR - 5 ) was obtained from Rubber Research Institute , India , Kottayam , with an average molecular weight of ~ 7,80,000 g mol −1 .
Blend preparation

iPP was dried in a vacuum oven at 80 °C for 6 h. To improve mixing efficiency , the high viscosity NR was reduced by masticating it for 5 min in a two - roll mill with a nip clearance of 3 mm and a friction ratio of 1.25:1 ( 20/15 rpm , back roll / front roll ) . Blends with different blend ratios of iPP and NR ( 100 – 0 , 90 – 10 , 80 – 20 , 70 – 30 60 – 40 and 50 – 50 ) were melt - mixed using a Brabender Plastocorder . The processing parameters , temperature , rotation per minute and time were fixed as 180 °C , 50 rpm and 10 min respectively .
entities: in a vacuum oven at 80 °C for 6 h.

brat_format_output.text: Characterization techniques
Differential scanning calorimetry ( DSC )

Perkin - Elmer ( Diamond series ) DSC was used to study the crystallization and melt - ing behavior , while TA instruments DSC ( Q 200 ) was used to study the Tg of the blends . Both DSCs were calibrated with indium standard under nitrogen atmosphere that was purged throughout the analysis to minimize thermo - oxidative degradation . Samples of weight 2 – 3 mg were used for each DSC experiment . The samples were exposed to different thermal histories :

1 . Isothermal crystallization : - Sample was heated up from 50 °C with a rate of 10 °C min −1 It was melted at a temperature ( Ta ) of 200 °C for 3 min , followed by cooling at a rate of 20 °C min −1 to crystallization temperatures ( Tc ) in the range of 124 to 136 °C and held until complete crystallization was recorded . The half - time of crystallization ( t 0.5 ) was determined at Tc = constant ( Refer Fig. 1 ) .2 . Melting behavior : Samples were heated from 50 to 200 °C at a rate of 10 °C min −1 and held for 3 min , followed by cooling with a rate of 20 °C min −1 to selected crystallization temperature ( Tc ) ranging between 124 to 136 °C and held for 5 ( t 0.5 ) . The sample was then reheated to 200 °C with a rate of 10 °C min −1.3 . Glass transition temperature : Sample was heated from 50 to 200 °C at a rate of 10 °C min −1 and held for 3 min , cooled to – 90 °C , held for 1 min then , reheated to 200 °C at a rate of 10 °C min −1 .

brat_format_output.text: Scanning electron microscopy ( SEM )

Morphological studies were carried out using a Scanning Electron Microscope ( SEM ) , JEOL ( model - JSM - 6390 ) operating at an acceleration voltage of 15 kV in a BSE ( backscattering electron ) . Hot press compression molded samples were cryo - genically fractured in liquid nitrogen to avoid phase deformation during the fracture process . The rubber phase was preferentially extracted using toluene as the solvent . The dried surfaces of samples were platinum coated before scanning .
entities: at an acceleration voltage of 15 kV

brat_format_output.text: Polarizing optical microscope ( POM ) : The diameter of the spherulites and spherulitic growth rate of blends were studied using Leica Q Win Software , which was attached to the Nikon microscope . The samples were cast onto cover slips and heated up from 30 °C with a rate of 10 °C min −1 . It was annealed at Ta = 200 °C for 3 min , followed by cooling with a rate of 20 °C min −1 to a pre-selected crystalliza - tion temperature ( Tc ) between 124 to 136 °C and held there until complete crystal - lization . Micrographs of iPP spherulites were captured at appropriate time intervals ( 30 s ) during isothermal crystallization .
entities: from 30 °C with a rate of 10 °C min −1

brat_format_output.text: Thermogravimetry
TGA measurements were performed using a TA instrument ( SDT Q600 ) at a heat - ing rate of 10 °C · min −1 . 10 – 20 mg of samples were heated from 0 to 700 °C under N2 atmosphere .
entities: at a heat - ing rate of 10 °C · min −1

brat_format_output.text: Results and discussion
Table 1 represents the results of glass transition temperature ( Tg ) obtained duringthe second heating cycle for iPP - NR blends ( Fig. 1 ) .

The Tg of iPP and NR were found to be − 7.8 and − 64.3 °C respectively . Two distinct Tg observed indicate that the amorphous fraction of iPP is immiscible with NR . Tg values were calculated using the half ∆ Cp extrapolation technique .
Cp = HF × 60 × K훽s × m0
where HF is the heat flow , βs represents the heating rate , m0 denotes sample mass , and K is the calibration constant , hence
K = standard Cpmeasured Cp ,

Composition - dependent variation in Tg can be observed due to the formation of a phase in phase morphology . The endothermic deviations obtained during the sec - ond heating cycle can be used to calculate the extent of cooperatively rearranging regions ( CRR ) ( ξ ) for the iPP phase using Donth ’s approximation ( 2 ) [ 25 – 27 ] , whichplays a vital role in the evaluation of the crystallinity .
휉 = kT2gΔC −1 p휌 ( 훿T ) 2 ,
where ρ the density of bulk material , ΔCp −1 is the reciprocal specific heat at con - stant pressure and δT . The result obtained is shown in Fig. 2 .
entities: at con - stant pressure and δT

brat_format_output.text: It can be observed that as the amount of NR increases , the ξ showed a gradual decrease which is in accordance with the morphology change observed using SEM . Gradual increases in the amount of NR result in a change from droplet - matrix to co-continuous type morphology . This is in exact correlation with calculated CRR values . In the case of the blend with 50 % · w / w of NR , an increase in CRR can be observed due to phase inversion . The crystallization of a semi-crystalline polymer in a blend can be affected by its counterpart . Molecular structure and molecular weight of the components , blend composition , type and degree of dispersion for dif - ferent phases in the molten stage , phase interaction at the interface of the individ - ual homopolymers and crystallization conditions are some of the major factors that affect the crystallinity in the polymer . The crystallinity ( χ ) [ 28 , 29 ] is given by ,
entities: as the amount of NR increases
blend with 50 % · w / w of NR

brat_format_output.text: 휒 % = ΔHmΔH ◦ m × Vf × 100 ,

where ΔHm and Vf are the enthalpy of fusion and volume fraction of iPP , respec - tively . The ΔH0m is the heat of fusion of 100 % pure crystalline PP which was taken as iPP is 209 J · g −1 . [ 30 ] The crystallinity increases with NR loading , reaches a maxi - mum of 30 % w / w of NR and thereafter decreases ( refer to Fig. 3 ) . The decrease in ξ and increase in χ indicate that small fractions of NR aid the crystallization of iPP by serving as nucleating agents , and the amorphous fraction of iPP has weak van der Waal ’s interaction with NR , with the interactions sensitive to NR loading . Figure 3 shows the melting curve for iPP – NR blend system ( Table 2 ) .

Endotherms for the second heating cycle were used to evaluate the melting behavior . This eliminates the influence of processing history on melting behavior . The melting temperature is almost the same in all blends ( ~ 163 °C ) . However , a small broadening of the melting peak can be observed , which may be due to the melting of different - sized crystals or disordered crystals formed by the addition of NR .

The endotherm obtained for iPP - NR blends after crystallization at selected crys - tallization temperatures ( Tc ) was used to calculate the equilibrium melting tempera - ture ( Tm ° ) using Hoffman – Weeks Eq . ( 4 ) [ 31 – 33 ] ,
Tm = Tc2훽 T0 m [ 1 −12 훽 ]

Here Tm is the melting temperature calculated at selected Tc and 훽 = lcl ∗ c is the thick - ening factor that is greater than or equal to one . Plot of Tmº against blend composi - tion is shown in Fig. 4 .

The trend for Tm ° has wide implications for polymer blends . An increasing value for Tm ° indicates that the crystalline fraction is compatible with the added amor - phous component . An increase in Tm ° is rarely encountered . A decrease in Tm ° indicates attractive interactions between the blend components . It can be observed from Fig. 4 that the Tm ° for iPP – NR blend shows a decreasing trend indicating that the crystalline fraction of iPP is having an attractive interaction with NR . Figure 5 shows the crystallization of iPP – NR blend at a selected Tc of 130 °C .

It follows from Fig. 6 that the addition of NR influenced the crystallization of iPP , and the rate of crystallization increased with the addition of NR . The broad - ened exotherm of neat iPP sharpens with NR loading , indicating favorable inter-action between iPP and NR . Neat iPP requires more time to crystallize than that of NR blended iPP , confirming the efficiency of NR as a nucleating agent . The isothermal crystallization studies were carried out to evaluate the crystallization kinetics for iPP – NR blends as a function of NR loading . The time taken for half the crystallinity to develop ( t 0.5 ) is recommended to remove the influence of the overall rate of crystallization on the phase boundaries of a heterogeneous system . Figure 6 shows a plot of t 0.5 against Tc ( 124 – 132 °C ) for iPP and iPP – NR blends .
The crystalline kinetics for polymeric materials can be best explained usingthe Avrami Eq . ( 5 ) [ 34 – 36 ] as ,
X ( t ) = 1 − exp [ − K1 ∕ n A t ] n

The conversion , X ( t ) , is the normalized crystallinity given as the ratio of the crystallinity at time , t , and the final crystallinity . KA1 / n and n represent the over-all rate of crystallization and the Avrami exponent respectively ( refer to Fig. 7 ) . Table 2 shows the value of K and n obtained for the PP - NR blend at different Tcs .

The Avrami exponent n is expected to have integral values , where a value between 1 and 2 represents 1D crystal growth , values between 2 and 3 indicate 2D crystal growth , while values between 3 and 4 represent 3D crystal growth and above 4 indicate heterogeneous nucleation . iPP – NR blends show a value of n close to 3 , indicating sporadic nucleation with 2 D crystal growth . The non-inte-gral value represents the non-Fickian contribution to the crystallization process . Figure 8 represents the plot of ( t 0.5 ) −1 against ( ΔTc ) −1 .
( t 0.5 ) −1 = A exp ( − BΔTc )

Here A is the frequency factor , and B is the ratio of energy densities in the lamella fold surface and bulk formulated using the Kelvin equation . Figure 8 can be used to calculate the activation energy for the crystallization of the crystalliz - able component ( here iPP ) in a polymer blend . A semi-logarithmic plot of ( t 0.5 ) −1 versus ( ∆ T ) −1 as shown in Fig. 8 , is linear in the Tc range investigated for neat iPP and iPP – NR blends . Figure 9 exhibits quantities ( Ea ) extracted from the slope ofthe semi-logarithmic plot of ( t 0.5 ) −1 versus ( ∆ T ) −1 for iPP in blends .

Figure 9 confirms that the Ea of iPP increases up to NR loading of 20 % · w / w , and thereafter it shows a decrease , while for a blend with 50 % · w / w of NR , it shows a substantial increase . The reason for this is the change in morphology ( from droplet - matrix type to co-continuous type ) , as discussed in the following section .

up to NR loading of 20 % · w / w

brat_format_output.text: SEM analysis shows droplet - matrix type morphology with gradual change to co-continuous type as a function of NR loading , ( 50 % · w / w NR loading onwards ) as evidenced by the SEM images shown in Fig. 10 .
Figure 11 displays the optical micrographs of spherulite growth at 130 °C at thecooling rate of 10 °C / min in neat iPP , and iPP – NR blend with magnification of 10X .
entities: at 130 °C at thecooling rate of 10 °C / min

brat_format_output.text: Figure 11a confirms the presence of a well - defined “ Maltese cross [ 14 ] ” coin - ciding with the principal axis of crystal and extinction direction of the polarizer / analyzer , indicating uniform crystal growth . Higher concentrations of NR exhibit co-continuous morphology , preventing the actual growth of iPP spherulites and disappearing Maltase cross for the spherulite developed in the iPP – NR 50 – 50 composition [ 37 , 38 ] . For a better understanding , magnified images 10 × are shown in Fig. 12 .

Spherulite growth rate ( G ) can be evaluated from the slope of the radius versus time curve , and Fig. 13a shows the growth rate for iPP , calculated from POM images . Figure 13b displays the contribution of the blend ratio on G over a different temperature range ( 124 – 136 °C ) . The spherulite growth rate reveals a decreasing pattern with increasing content of NR , and it is prominent at lower crystallization temperatures .

However , G is unaffected by the blend ratio at higher Tc . This can be due to the slower growth rate because of the high molecular mobility . TGA and DTA plots for iPP and iPP – NR blends are shown in Fig. 14a , b respectively .

The experiment was performed between temperature ranges of 30 to 700 °C . Fig - ure 14a shows that neat iPP has single - step degradation with high thermal stabil - ity ( decomposition onset of 385 °C ) , while 50 % of degradation occurs at 474 °C . With the addition of NR to the iPP matrix , a gradual decrement of onset of degra - dation reaching up to 308 °C can be observed ( 50 % ∙ w / w of NR ) . It is noteworthy that blends of iPP – NR exhibit two degradation steps , indicating a highly immiscible system , which is obvious from the DTG curves ( Fig. 3 ) . Peak obtained in the range of 350 to 400 °C represents the degradation of NR , while iPP degradation occurred at 450 to 500 °C .
entities: With the addition of NR to the iPP matrix

brat_format_output.text: Conclusion

The crystallization kinetics , spherulitic growth rate and melting properties of iPP blended with non-polar counterpart have been evaluated and correlated to blend morphology . The addition of NR to iPP produces a gradual change in morphology from droplet - matrix to co-continuous type , and this resulted in a predominant con - tribution to the crystallization kinetics of iPP and the mutual interaction between the blend components . Decrease in Tm ° with NR loading , point to the existence of weak attractive interactions between the blend components . This is also reflected in the spherulite growth rate . Even though the blending of iPP with other polymers has been studied and reported quite extensively , the effect of dynamic asymmetry on thermal properties and morphology development remains unexplored . Considering the commercial importance of iPP in various sectors , a detailed evaluation of the effect of molecular weight on thermal , mechanical and morphological properties is extremely important . The present study will usher in the development of iPP - based blends and nanocomposites with improved thermal and mechanical properties .
